newsitem.title: JAPAN: Cell phone, Internet craze to boost NTT profit.
newsitem.headline: Cell phone, Internet craze to boost NTT profit.

text.p: Japanese telecoms giant NTT is expected to ring up higher annual profits on the back of a boom in cellular phones and Japan's growing obsession with the Internet.

Analysts say soaring demand for portable phone services and increasing Web traffic will mean Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp, with its 99 percent monopoly of Japan's local-call network, will post a rosy set of earnings figures for the fiscal year which ended on March 31.

They expect NTT's parent current profits to rise by 10 percent or more to around 360 billion to 400 billion yen ($2.25 billion to $3.44 billion) for the 1996/97 year, after profit more than doubled in 1995/96 to 328.92 billion yen ($2.83 billion).
Current profit is pretax and includes gains or losses on non-operating activities such as investments in stocks.
NTT will announce parent as well as group-based business results for fiscal 1996/97 on May 23. It will also unveil its forecast for 1997/98.

Growing investment by Japanese firms in digital information, rising phone traffic and a planned restructuring of NTT into a set of leaner companies will keep profits on a rising curve in the future, analysts said.
"Local call traffic will continue increasing at least by 10 percent annually over the next few years," said Toshiaki Iba, an analyst at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson.

Hironobu Sawake, an analyst at Nikko Research Center, said: "NTT will be encouraged to undertake restructuring to improve its profit margins, following a compromise with the government on a break-up structure for NTT."
A government decision to break up NTT into three companies under a single holding firm in around 1999 is due to be formally approved by parliament next month.
Analysts say NTT should manage to boost its parent current profit to around 450 billion to 490 billion yen ($2.81 billion to $4.22 billion) in the business year to next March 31.
Riding high on the buoyant business prospects, NTT's share price rose to its highest level so far this calendar year on Monday, standing at 1.08 million yen ($9,300).

Interconnection charges from traditional cellular phone operators are likely to have more than doubled to around 330 billion yen ($2.84 billion) in the just-ended business year, analysts said, providing a major boost to profits.

Charges for connecting competitors' fragmented networks with NTT's local-call network should top 400 billion yen ($3.44 billion) when fees paid by PHS (personal handyphone system) operators and long-distance operators are included. PHS is a new, low-cost cellular phone system developed in Japan.

But NTT's net profit will stay flat on a group basis in 1996/97 because profit from NTT's own cellular phone unit, NTT Mobile Communications Network Inc (NTT Docomo), was wiped out by a loss at an NTT PHS unit.
The result for 1995/96 had been helped by capital gains from the sale of shares in a data communications unit which went public in April 1995.

"NTT's group profit will jump this year and over the next few years, helped by a steady increase in profit at the two units (cell phone and data communications) as well as the parent company," said Hironori Tanaka, an analyst at Yamaichi Research Institute of Securities and Economics.
"NTT, with its solid earnings structure, is unlikely to be affected by rate cuts in long-distance services any more," he added.
